item.description:
Each week, first listen to the audio lecture. (Because most of the speakers could not assume that their audience consisted of experts, the lectures generally serve as a great introduction to the topic.) Second, glance over (but do not yet try to answer) the study questions. Finally - and this will take the bulk of the week's time - tackle the reading(s), answering the study questions as you go along. Write down any questions that arise as you go through the materials and we will go over these and the study questions when we meet up each Wednesday.

Audio:

"Profit, Loss, and Entrepeneurship"
Salerno, Mises University (2001)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuKIvN94geQ
Readings:

"A Place Where Nothing Ever Happens: On the Employment of Imaginary Constructs in Economics"
"Butcher, Baker, Candlestick Maker: On Economic Roles and the Theory of Distribution"
Callahan, Economics for Real People, chapters 6 and 7
http://mises.org/books/econforrealpeople.pdf
"From an Evenly Rotating Economy to the Real World"
Taylor, An Introduction to Austrian Economics, chapter7
http://mises.org/books/introtoaustrian.pdf
Study Questions:

1. What is the difference between profit and interest?

2. Which imaginary construction is useful for illustrating the difference?

3. How do Austrians justify the use of imaginary constructions?

4. Is there a "normal rate of profit" in a market economy?

5. In what sense is all action entrepreneurial?

6. How does entrepreneurship relate to consumer satisfaction?

7. What is the connection between disequilibrium and entrepreneurship?

8. What does the "market process" mean?

9. What does Mises say is the "ultimate source" of profits and losses?

10. Isn't it true that one man's profit is another's loss?
item.name: Austrian Economics Meetup: Profit, Loss, And Entrepreneurship
